prompt: 1. Draw an architecture diagram showing a service `web` (server icon, title 'Web Server') connected from its right port (`R`) to the left port (`L`) of service `db` (database icon, title 'Database'). Also connect `web`'s bottom port (`B`) to the top port (`T`) of service `cache` (disk icon, title 'Cache').
output:
architecture-beta
    service web(server)[Web Server]
    service db(database)[Database]
    service cache(disk)[Cache]

    web:R -- L:db
    web:B -- T:cache

prompt: 2. Create an architecture diagram with a group `cloud_env` (cloud icon, title 'Cloud Environment'). Inside this group, place two services: `app` (server icon, 'Application') and `storage` (disk icon, 'File Storage'). Connect `app`'s right port (`R`) to `storage`'s left port (`L`).
output:
architecture-beta
    group cloud_env(cloud)[Cloud Environment]

    service app(server)[Application] in cloud_env
    service storage(disk)[File Storage] in cloud_env

    app:R -- L:storage

prompt: 3. Draw an architecture diagram featuring a service `api` (server, 'API Gateway') connected from its bottom port (`B`) to the top port (`T`) of service `auth` (server, 'Auth Service'), and also from its right port (`R`) to the left port (`L`) of service `users` (database, 'User DB').
output:
```mermaid
architecture-beta
    service api(server)[API Gateway]
    service auth(server)[Auth Service]
    service users(database)[User DB]

    api:B -- T:auth
    api:R -- L:users
```

prompt: 4. Construct an architecture diagram with three services: `frontend` (internet, 'UI'), `backend` (server, 'Backend API'), and `data` (database, 'Data Store').     service backend(server)[Backend API]
    service data(database)[Data Store]

    frontend:B --> T:backend
    backend:R --> L:data
```

prompt: 5. Design an architecture diagram with a group `vpc` (cloud, 'Virtual Cloud'). Inside `vpc`, place services `web1` (server, 'Web Instance 1') and `web2` (server, 'Web Instance 2'). output:

    group vpc(cloud)[Virtual Cloud]

    lb:B -- T:web1

```

prompt: 15. Draw an architecture diagram with a central junction `j_main`. Connect service `input1` (internet, 'Input 1') right port (`R`) to `j_main` left port (`L`). Connect service `input2` (internet, 'Input 2') bottom port (`B`) to `j_main` top port (`T`). Connect `j_main` right port (`R`) to service `output1` (database, 'Output 1') left port (`L`). Connect `j_main` top port (`T`) to service `output2` (disk, 'Output 2') bottom port (`B`).
output:
```mermaid
architecture-beta
    // Declare services
    service input1(internet)[Input 1]
    service input2(internet)[Input 2]
    service output1(database)[Output 1]
    service output2(disk)[Output 2]

    // Declare junction
    junction j_main

    // Define connections
    input1:R -- L:j_main  // Input 1 Right to Junction Left
    input2:B -- T:j_main  // Input 2 Bottom to Junction Top
    j_main:R -- L:output1 // Junction Right to Output 1 Left
    j_main:T -- B:output2 // Junction Top to Output 2 Bottom
```

prompt: 100. Full stack example: `Browser` (server, "Client"):R --> `L:CDN`. `CDN` (internet, "CDN"):R --> `L:LoadBalancer`. `LoadBalancer` (internet, "LB"):B --> `T:WebServer1{group}`. Group `FrontendGroup` (cloud, "Frontend") containing `WebServer1`, `WebServer2` (server, "Web") (`in FrontendGroup`). Group `APIGroup` (cloud, "API") containing `APIServer1`, `APIServer2` (server, "API Srv") (`in APIGroup`). Group `BackendGroup` (cloud, "Backend") containing `WorkerService` (server, "Worker") and `MainDatabase` (database, "DB") (`in BackendGroup`). Connect `WebServer1{group}:B` --> `T:APIServer1{group}`. Connect `APIServer1{group}:B` --> `T:WorkerService{group}`. Connect `APIServer1`:R --> `L:MainDatabase`. Connect `WorkerService`:R --> `L:MainDatabase`. Connect `WebServer1`:R <--> `L:WebServer2`. Connect `APIServer1`:R <--> `L:APIServer2`.
output:
architecture-beta
    // Standalone Services
    service Browser(server)[Client]
    service CDN(internet)[CDN]
    service LoadBalancer(internet)[LB]

    // Groups
    group FrontendGroup(cloud)[Frontend]
    group APIGroup(cloud)[API]
    group BackendGroup(cloud)[Backend]

    // Services in Groups
    service WebServer1(server)[Web] in FrontendGroup
    service WebServer2(server)[Web] in FrontendGroup
    service APIServer1(server)[API Srv] in APIGroup
    service APIServer2(server)[API Srv] in APIGroup
    service WorkerService(server)[Worker] in BackendGroup
    service MainDatabase(database)[DB] in BackendGroup

    // Edges
    Browser:R --> L:CDN
    CDN:R --> L:LoadBalancer
    LoadBalancer:B --> T:WebServer1{group}
    WebServer1{group}:B --> T:APIServer1{group}
    APIServer1{group}:B --> T:WorkerService{group}
    APIServer1:R --> L:MainDatabase
    WorkerService:R --> L:MainDatabase
    WebServer1:R <--> L:WebServer2
    APIServer1:R <--> L:APIServer2

Deployment_Node(dev_env, 'Dev Server'). Deployment_Node(staging_env, 'Staging Server'). Rel(repo, builder, 'Triggers build'). Rel(builder, artifact_store, 'Stores artifact'). Rel(builder, tester, 'Triggers tests'). Rel(tester, deployer, 'Triggers deployment'). Rel(deployer, dev_env). Rel(deployer, staging_env). Rel(deployer, artifact_store, 'Retrieves artifact').
output:
C4Container
  title CI/CD Pipeline

  System_Ext(repo, 'Code Repository', 'GitLab')
  System_Ext(sys_dev_env, 'Dev Server', 'Deployment Target')
  System_Ext(sys_staging_env, 'Staging Server', 'Deployment Target')

  Container_Boundary(pipeline, 'CI/CD Pipeline') {
    Container(builder, 'Build Agent', 'Docker', 'Compiles code')
    ContainerDb(artifact_store, 'Artifact Storage', 'Nexus/Artifactory', 'Stores build artifacts')
    Container(tester, 'Test Runner', 'Docker', 'Runs unit/integration tests')
    Container(deployer, 'Deployment Agent', 'Ansible', 'Deploys to servers')
  }

  Rel(repo, builder, 'Triggers build')
  Rel(builder, artifact_store, 'Stores artifact')
  Rel(builder, tester, 'Triggers tests')
  Rel(tester, deployer, 'Triggers deployment')
  Rel_Back(deployer, artifact_store, 'Retrieves artifact') ' Using Rel_Back for visual separation
  Rel(deployer, sys_dev_env, 'Deploys to')
  Rel(deployer, sys_staging_env, 'Deploys to')

  ' Adjustments for clarity and spacing
  UpdateRelStyle(repo, builder, $offsetY="-40")
  UpdateRelStyle(builder, artifact_store, $offsetX="-60", $offsetY="20")
  UpdateRelStyle(builder, tester, $offsetX="70")
  UpdateRelStyle(tester, deployer, $offsetX="70")
  UpdateRelStyle(deployer, artifact_store, $offsetY="-40")
  UpdateRelStyle(deployer, sys_dev_env, $offsetX="-60", $offsetY="40")
  UpdateRelStyle(deployer, sys_staging_env, $offsetX="60", $offsetY="40")

prompt: 81. Design a sequence diagram for distributed transaction (2PC): Coordinator ->> P1: Prepare. Coordinator ->> P2: Prepare. par P1 Response: P1 -->> Coordinator: Prepared OK. and P2 Response: P2 -->> Coordinator: Prepared OK. end alt All Prepared OK: Coordinator ->> P1: Commit. Coordinator ->> P2: Commit. else Any Failed: Coordinator ->> P1: Abort. Coordinator ->> P2: Abort. end
output:
sequenceDiagram

    participant P1
    participant P2

    Coordinator->>P2: Prepare

    par P1 Response
        P1-->>Coordinator: Prepared OK
    and P2 Response
        P2-->>Coordinator: Prepared OK
    end

    alt All Prepared OK
        Coordinator->>P1: Commit
        Coordinator->>P2: Commit
    else Any Failed
        Coordinator->>P1: Abort
        Coordinator->>P2: Abort
    end

Inside MicroserviceA's block, if validation fails (conceptual), MicroserviceA sends `@return Client->MicroserviceA: ErrorA`. If validation passes, MicroserviceA returns normally. Only if MicroserviceA returns normally, Orchestrator proceeds to call sync `CallB()` on MicroserviceB.

Inside B's block: B calls sync `Step1()` on C (`res1 = C.Step1()`). B calls sync `Step2()` on C (`res2 = C.Step2()`). B processes `res1` and `res2` and uses `return combined_result`.

SystemB performs work internally. SystemB sends `@return SystemA->SystemB: Process Complete`. SystemB also sends a separate async message `Notify` to SystemC.

Frontend calls sync `Login(user, pass)` on Backend. Inside Backend's block, it calls sync `Authenticate(user, pass)` on AuthSvc. AuthSvc uses `return authToken`. Backend uses `return authToken`.

Draw a ZenUML diagram with a nested synchronous call where both levels use the `return` keyword. Participants: Caller, Mid, Target. Caller calls sync `OuterCall()` on Mid. Draw a complex ZenUML diagram: Creation, Sync, Async, Loop, @return. Participants: Client, JobFactory, Worker, Notifier. Client sends async `RequestJobs(count)` to JobFactory. Draw a complex ZenUML diagram: If/Else If/Else with Nested Sync and Annotators. Participants: @Actor User, @Service Orchestrator, @Service ServiceA, @Service ServiceB, @Database AuditDB. User sends async `SubmitRequest(type, data)` to Orchestrator. Orchestrator calls sync `LogEvent("Received")` on AuditDB. Orchestrator has `if(type == 'TypeA')` block: calls sync `ProcessA(data)` on ServiceA. Inside ServiceA's block, it calls sync `SubProcessA1()` on itself. `else if(type == 'TypeB')` block: calls sync `ProcessB(data)` on ServiceB. `else` block: calls sync `HandleInvalidType(type)` on itself. Finally, Orchestrator calls sync `LogEvent("Completed")` on AuditDB.

Draw the most complex ZenUML diagram: Title, Alias, Annotator, Sync, Async, Nesting, Loop, If, Opt, Par, Try/Catch/Finally, Return. Participants: @Actor C as Client, GW as Gateway, @Control Auth, @Service S1, @Service S2, @Database DB, Log. Title: 'Advanced Order Flow'. C sends async `PlaceOrder(order)` to GW. GW calls sync `Authenticate(token)` on Auth (`auth_res = Auth.Authenticate(token)`). GW has `if(auth_res == 'OK')` block: enters `try { }` block. Inside `try`: GW calls sync `ReserveItems(order.items)` on S1 (`res_id = S1.ReserveItems(order.items)`). Inside S1's `ReserveItems`: S1 enters `for(item : order.items)` loop: calls sync `CheckStock(item)` on DB. After loop, S1 enters `par { }` block: sends async `UpdateInventory` to DB, sends async `NotifyWarehouse` to S2. S1 returns `res_id`. GW then calls sync `ProcessPayment(order.payment)` on S2. GW uses `return order_confirmation`. `catch { }` block: GW sends async `OrderFailed` to C. `finally { }` block: GW sends async `LogTransaction` to Log. After successful try, GW has `opt { }` block: sends async `SendConfirmationEmail` to C. `else` block (auth failed): GW sends async `AuthError` to C.

Draw a ZenUML diagram showing a Try/Catch block around object creation and usage. Participants: Creator, RiskyBuilder, FallbackBuilder, Product. Creator calls sync `CreateProduct()` on itself. Draw a ZenUML diagram where an If/Else If/Else structure determines the recipient of a message. Participants: Router, ServiceEast, ServiceWest, ServiceCentral, Client. Draw a ZenUML diagram combining Alt (if/else) and Opt fragments. Participants: Configurator, Service1, Service2, Logger. Configurator receives `mode`. prompt: Draw an Order Processing flowchart using block diagram shapes: 'Start' (circle), 'ValidateOrder' (rhombus), 'CheckInventory' (subroutine), 'ProcessPayment' (stadium), 'ShipOrder' (parallelogram '/'), 'UpdateDB' (cylindrical), 'End' (double circle). Use columns and spaces for layout. Link Start -> ValidateOrder. Link ValidateOrder --'OK'-> CheckInventory. Link ValidateOrder --'Fail'-> End. Link CheckInventory --'In Stock'-> ProcessPayment. Link CheckInventory --'Out Stock'-> End. Link ProcessPayment --'Success'-> ShipOrder. Link ProcessPayment --'Fail'-> End. Link ShipOrder -> UpdateDB -> End. Define and apply a class 'failPath' with red stroke to the 'Fail' links or blocks.
output:
block-beta
  columns 4

  %% Row 1: Start
  space Start(("Start")) space:2

  %% Vertical Spacer
  space:4

  %% Row 2: Validate Order + Fail Path End
  space ValidateOrder{{"Validate Order"}} space End1((("End")))

  %% Vertical Spacer
  space:4

  %% Row 3: Check Inventory + Fail Path End
  space CheckInventory[["Check Inventory"]] space End2((("End")))

  %% Vertical Spacer
  space:4

  %% Row 4: Process Payment + Fail Path End
  space ProcessPayment(["Process Payment"]) space End3((("End")))

  %% Vertical Spacer
  space:4

  %% Row 5: Ship Order
  space ShipOrder[/"Ship Order"/] space:2

  %% Vertical Spacer
  space:4

  %% Row 6: Update DB
  space UpdateDB[("Update DB")] space:2

  %% Vertical Spacer
  space:4

  %% Row 7: Success Path End
  space EndSuccess((("End"))) space:2


  %% Define connections
  Start --> ValidateOrder
  ValidateOrder -- "OK" --> CheckInventory
  ValidateOrder -- "Fail" --> End1
  CheckInventory -- "In Stock" --> ProcessPayment
  CheckInventory -- "Out Stock" --> End2
  ProcessPayment -- "Success" --> ShipOrder
  ProcessPayment -- "Fail" --> End3
  ShipOrder --> UpdateDB
  UpdateDB --> EndSuccess

  %% Define and Apply Styles
  classDef failPath stroke:#f00,stroke-width:2px;
  class End1,End2,End3 failPath
  linkStyle 2 stroke:#f00,stroke-width:2px; %% ValidateOrder -- "Fail" --> End1
  linkStyle 4 stroke:#f00,stroke-width:2px; %% CheckInventory -- "Out Stock" --> End2
  linkStyle 6 stroke:#f00,stroke-width:2px; %% ProcessPayment -- "Fail" --> End3

prompt: Generate a complex ER diagram with 7 entities (e.g., University: University, Faculty, Department, Course, Student, Professor, Enrollment) showing multiple relationships (1:1, 1:N, M:N resolved), attributes with keys (PK, FK, UK), comments, and some entity aliases.
output:
erDiagram
    UNIVERSITY ||--|{ FACULTY : has
    FACULTY ||--|{ DEPARTMENT : contains
    DEPARTMENT ||--|{ PROFESSOR : employs
    DEPARTMENT ||--|{ COURSE : offers
    STUDENT }o..|| DEPARTMENT : "majors in"
    PROFESSOR ||..o{ COURSE : teaches
    STUDENT ||--|{ ENROLLMENT : "records"
    COURSE ||--|{ ENROLLMENT : "details"

    UNIVERSITY {
        int universityId PK "Unique ID for the university"
        string name UK
        string address
    }
    FACULTY {
        int facultyId PK
        string name UK
        string deanName "Name of the Dean"
        int universityId FK "References UNIVERSITY"
    }
    DEPARTMENT [Dept] {
        int deptId PK
        string name UK "Department name (e.g., Computer Science)"
        int facultyId FK "References FACULTY"
    }
    COURSE {
        string courseId PK "e.g., CS101"
        string title
        int credits "Number of credits"
        int deptId FK "References Dept offering the course"
    }
    PROFESSOR [Prof] {
        int professorId PK
        string firstName
        string lastName
        string email UK
        string officeNumber
        int deptId FK "References Dept"
    }
    STUDENT [Stu] {
        int studentId PK "Unique student identifier"
        string firstName
        string lastName
        string email UK
        date enrollmentDate
        int deptId FK "References Major Department (Dept)"
    }
    ENROLLMENT {
        int studentId PK, FK "Part of composite PK, references Stu"
        string courseId PK, FK "Part of composite PK, references COURSE"
        string semester PK "Part of composite PK, e.g., Fall 2024"
        string grade "e.g., A, B+, IP (In Progress)"
    }

Inside: Transactor sends 'Notify Failure A' to Notifier (`->>`). End option. Use 'option' 'Lock B Failed'. Inside: Transactor sends 'Unlock A' to ResourceA (`->>`). Transactor sends 'Notify Failure B' to Notifier (`->>`). End option. If locks succeed: Transactor sends 'Perform Action A' to ResourceA (`->>`). Transactor sends 'Perform Action B' to ResourceB (`->>`). Transactor sends 'Unlock A' to ResourceA (`->>`). Transactor sends 'Unlock B' to ResourceB (`->>`). End critical.         Transactor->>Notifier: Notify Failure B
    %% Success Path (if no options triggered)
        Transactor->>ResourceA: Perform Action A
        Transactor->>ResourceB: Perform Action B
        Transactor->>ResourceA: Unlock A
        Transactor->>ResourceB: Unlock B
    end

prompt: Create a sequence diagram involving a break statement within nested loops. Participants: Analyzer, DataSource, Processor. Analyzer enters 'loop' 'Outer Loop'. Inside: Analyzer sends 'Fetch Batch' to DataSource (`->>`). DataSource replies 'Batch Data' to Analyzer (`-->>`). Analyzer enters 'loop' 'Inner Loop (Process Items)'. Inside: Analyzer sends 'Get Next Item' to itself (`->>`). Use 'alt' 'Item Type'. Condition 'Type Error': Use 'break' 'Error Found'. Inside break: Analyzer sends 'Log Error' to itself (`->>`). End break. Condition 'Type Data': Analyzer sends 'Process Item' to Processor (`->>`). Processor replies 'Item Processed' to Analyzer (`-->>`). End alt. End 'Inner Loop'. End 'Outer Loop'. Analyzer sends 'Analysis Complete' to itself (`->>`).

            end
        end

    Analyzer->>Analyzer: Analysis Complete

prompt: Draw a complex sequence diagram with 6 participants (A, B, C, D, E, F), involving parallel calls, conditional logic, loops, and activations. A sends 'Start' to B (`->>+`). B enters 'loop' 'Main Process'. Inside loop: Use 'par'. Action 1: B sends 'Task 1' to C (`->>+`). Action 2: B sends 'Task 2' to D (`->>+`). End par. C replies 'Result 1' to B (`-->>-`). D replies 'Result 2' to B (`-->>-`). Use 'alt' 'Check Results'. Condition 'Error in Results': B sends 'Log Error' to F (`->>`). Break loop (conceptual, not explicit break syntax). Else 'Results OK': B sends 'Forward Results' to E (`->>+`). E replies 'Acknowledged' to B (`-->>-`). End alt. End loop. B replies 'Finished' to A (`-->>-`).
output:
sequenceDiagram
    participant A
    participant B
    participant C
    participant D
    participant E
    participant F

    A->>+B: Start

    loop Main Process
        par Task 1 and Task 2
            B->>+C: Task 1
        and
            B->>+D: Task 2
        end
        C-->>-B: Result 1
        D-->>-B: Result 2

        alt Check Results
            option Error in Results
                B->>F: Log Error
                break Error Occurred
                end
            option Results OK
                B->>+E: Forward Results
                E-->>-B: Acknowledged
        end
    end

    B-->>-A: Finished

prompt: Generate a sequence diagram with nested critical sections. Participants: Orchestrator, Service1, Resource1, Service2, Resource2. Orchestrator starts 'critical' 'Outer Transaction'. Inside: Orchestrator sends 'Prepare S1' to Service1 (`->>`). Service1 starts 'critical' 'Resource 1 Access'. Inside: Service1 sends 'Lock R1' to Resource1 (`->>`). Option 'R1 Lock Failed': Service1 sends 'Abort S1' to Orchestrator (`->>`). End Option. End inner critical. Orchestrator sends 'Prepare S2' to Service2 (`->>`). Service2 starts 'critical' 'Resource 2 Access'. Inside: Service2 sends 'Lock R2' to Resource2 (`->>`). Option 'R2 Lock Failed': Service2 sends 'Abort S2' to Orchestrator (`->>`). End Option.     participant Service1
    participant Resource1
    participant Service2
    participant Resource2

        Orchestrator->>Service1: Prepare S1
        critical Resource 1 Access
            Service1->>Resource1: Lock R1
        option R1 Lock Failed
            Service1->>Orchestrator: Abort S1
        end

        Orchestrator->>Service2: Prepare S2
        critical Resource 2 Access
            Service2->>Resource2: Lock R2
        option R2 Lock Failed
            Service2->>Orchestrator: Abort S2
        end

    option Any Abort Occurred
        Orchestrator->>Orchestrator: Rollback All
    end

prompt: Draw a sequence diagram illustrating a complex retry loop using `loop` and `alt`. Participants: Client, Gateway, Service. Client sends 'Attempt Request' to Gateway (`->>`). Condition 'Success': Service replies 'OK' to Gateway (`-->>-`). Break loop (conceptual). Else 'Failure': Service replies 'Error' to Gateway (`--x-`). Add Note right of Gateway: 'Increment retry counter'. End alt. End loop. Gateway replies final status ('OK' or 'Error') to Client (`-->>`).
output:
sequenceDiagram
    participant Client
    participant Gateway
    participant Service

    Client->>Gateway: Attempt Request
    loop Retry up to 3 times
        Gateway->>+Service: Forward Request
        alt Service Response
            Service-->>-Gateway: OK
            %% Mermaid doesn't have an explicit loop break;
            %% success implies loop exit after this iteration.
        else Failure
            Service--x-Gateway: Error
            Note right of Gateway: Increment retry counter
        end
    end
    Gateway-->>Client: Final Status (OK or Error)
